Depression Definitions:

Clinical depression is a consistent depressed mood, lasting longer than two weeks, in which an individual loses interest and pleasure in their regular activities. Depression affects an individuals’ daily life including personal relationships, work and their mental and physical health. Symptoms may be mild to severe and may be short-term or long-lasting. The most severe cases of depression may lead to suicide or attempted suicide.

 Statistics:


Depression is the leading cause of disability in the United States among individuals ages 15-44

2/3 of individuals with depression do not seek treatment.

For those that receive treatment for the disorder, about 80% see an improvement within 6 weeks of their treatment.

The Center for Disease Control estimated over 44,000 suicides occurred in 2015.

Suicide is in the top 10 leading causes of death in the United States.

 Symptoms of Depression:


Loss of interest and pleasure in regular activities/hobbies

General apathy

Excessive sleep

Suicidal thoughts

Social isolation

Abuse Definitions:

Abuse can come in many different forms as physical and emotional abuse are just broad categories for the many different ways a person can be abused. They often inflict life-altering symptoms onto survivors of abuse depending on the type of abuse. These symptoms can be managed through therapy and can be learned to cope with over time. Abuse doesn’t just ruin the survivor’s life, it also deteriorates the abuser’s life too if they never learn to change.

 Statistics:


Relationship violence accounts for 15% of all violent crimes.

Almost 1/5 domestic violence cases involve a weapon.

Only 1/3 of victims seek medical treatment for their injuries after being hurt by an intimate partner.

 Symptoms of Abuse for Survivors:


Chronic anxiety

Anger/Irritable

Signs of PTSD

Trust issues

 Traits of an Abuser:


Overly physical/violent behavior

Gaslighting

Forcing others into uncomfortable situations

 Sources/Additional Information


Child Abuse Facts: dosomething.org

Learn About Therapy: goodtherapy.org

Abuse Statistics: ncadv.org

PTSD Definitions:

Posttraumatic stress disorder is an emotional illness that can often be found when the user has undergone devastating or extreme events/experiences. More often than not, war veterans are usually diagnosed with PTSD because of the extreme events that war puts soldiers through. Rape, sexual assault, and abuse are also common events that can cause PTSD.

 Statistics:


14% of adults in the U.S. go on to develop PTSD at least once in their lives.

Women are about twice as likely as men to develop PTSD.

About 20% of soldiers develop PTSD.

Somewhat higher rates of PTSD have been found to occur in African Americans, Hispanics, and Native Americans compared to Caucasians in the United States.

 Symptoms of PTSD:


Recurring experience of the trauma

Recurring nightmares

Extreme avoidance of anything related to the trauma

Significant negative changes to thinking and behavior

 Sources/Additional Information


Info on PTSD: nimh.nih.gov

PTSD Statistics: healmyptsd.com

Sexual Assault Definitions:

Sexual assault can be broadly defined as an unwanted act of either penetration (penal, or object), contact with sexual body parts or exposure of intimate body parts. Definition and laws can vary widely between states.

 Statistics:


Females of age 16-19 are 4 times more likely than the general population to be victims of sexual assault.

On average, there are 321,500 victims (age 12+) of sexual assault each year in America which leads to an estimate of one victim every 98 seconds in the United States.

Approximately 10% of rape victims are male.

Women ages 18-24 who are college students are 3 times more likely than women in general to experience sexual violence. Females of the same age who are not enrolled in college are 4 times more likely.

 Warning Signs of Sexual Assault:


Their partner is secluding them from other relationships

Pressured into unsafe sexual practices (i.e. no condoms/birth control)

Forced to spend less time doing other activities

Partner is overbearing, manipulative and/or controlling

 Sources/Additional Information


Rape, Abuse and Incest National Network: rainn.org
